title: Fears 74 dead migrants washed ashore may have been murdered as they fled their homes - Mirror Online
text:
News Fears 74 dead migrants washed ashore may have been murdered as they fled their homes WARNING GRAPHIC IMAGES The 71 men and three women who drowned at the weekend are likely to be from sub-Sahara Share Libyan Red Crescent shows volunteers of the Red Crescent recovering bodies washed ashore at the coast near Al Zawiya (Photo: LIBYAN RED CRESCENT) Share Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
Scores of migrants washed ashore on a beach may have been murdered . 
The 71 men and three women who drowned at the weekend are likely to be from sub-Sahara. 
Police and officials are trying to identify those killed, all of whom are believed to have drowned whilst fleeing the North African country. 
The corpses landed near the western Libyan city of Zawiya, according to the Red Crescent aid agency, and were all adults, mostly men with three women among them. 
Spokesman for Red Crescent Mohamed al-Misrati said the bodies had been recovered on Monday and that the migrants appeared to have died during the past two days. 
It is believed they were mostly from African sub-Saharan countries. 
The Red Crescent published pictures of the bodies laid out in white and black body bags along the beach. The beach became a graveyard for tragic migrants (Photo: Libyan Red Crescent) A torn rubber dinghy was found nearby (Photo: Libyan Red Crescent) 
Libya is the main departure point for migrants hoping to flee war, poverty and oppression to reach Europe by sea. 
Mostly they try to cross in flimsy inflatable craft loaded with small amounts of fuel which are intended to get them only as far as European rescue vessels stationed in international waters. 
Several British warships have taken part in massive rescue operations in which thousands of migrants have been pulled out of the water just out of sight of the coast of Libya. Red Crescent workers carry one of the bodies off the beach in a bodybag (Photo: Libyan Red Crescent) (Photo: Libyan Red Crescent) 
Royal Navy warships involved in rescue operations stay out of sight of the Libyan coast for fear of being hit by al-Qaeda or Islamic State missiles. 
British Royal Navy ships like HMS Bulwark have in the past then taken the migrants on to drop-off points in Sicily, where they are processed, given food and shelter and can have asylum claims scrutinised. 
People smugglers - many of whom have deals with Islamic State terrorists - can make hundreds of thousnds of pounds from each boatload. The body bags are labelled before being moved off the beach (Photo: Libyan Red Crescent) The bodies were recovered on the beach (Photo: Libyan Red Crescent) 
The badly-made migrant boats have to travel 800 miles to Libya and often capsize so an international armada of rescue ships is on daily patrol to stop passengers drowning. 
The ruthless trafficking gangs are being hunted down by western special forces and Italian police - with rescue boats carrying detailed descriptions and photographs of the ring-leaders. 
The Daily Mirror has seen British Royal Marines arresting several suspected people smugglers aboard a sinking boat as they were brought onto HMS Bulwark. Red Crescent workers walk back down the beach to collect more corpses (Photo: Libyan Red Crescent) 
The men were then handed over to a Sicilian special investigations unit and it is believed they were trying to pretend to be migrants and set up a base in Sicily. 
Most depart from the stretch of Libyan coast between Tripoli and the Tunisian border to the west. 
The bodies of those who drown are frequently found washed up on Libyan shores- victims of Mediterranean storms or vicious tides. More than 270 people migrating are believed to have drowned in the Mediterranean in the first weeks of 2017 (Photo: Libyan Red Crescent) 
Last year a record 181,000 migrants crossed between Libya and Italy. More than 4,500 are known to have died. 
Having largely closed off sea crossings between Turkey and Greece last year, the European Union is searching for ways to stem the flow of migrants from Libya. 
This month European leaders offered Libya money and other assistance to try to reduce the numbers departing across the Mediterranean. 
Aid groups criticised the move, saying such plans exposed migrants to further risks and abuses within Libya. Like us on Facebook
